concept.title: Beam oak vs. wild oak
concept.shortdesc: Here you will learn about differences between beam oak and wild oak.

conbody.p: Beam oak or wild oak is not understood to mean a type of tree in the traditional sense, nor is it a special type of wood. Rather, the term relates to a special sorting of the trees, which have to meet certain criteria during the selection and also during production. You can find out what these are here.

section.title: Wild oak
section.p: Wild oaks are oaks that have an exceptionally lively and expressive grain. Trees in shady locations, preferably on the edge of the forest, have such characteristics. In addition, only trees with an above-average number of knotholes are used. In technical jargon, the wild oak is therefore also called knotty oak.
section.note:
After cutting, wood is divided into different grades. These are timber trade classes that differ in terms of various optical features and properties.
Particularly strikingly grained wooden parts are used in the manufacture of wild oak furniture. Visible knots as well as darker and lighter wood sections complete the picture. The use of the expressive wood creates furniture that with its natural charisma attracts everyone's attention.

section.title: Beam oak
section.p: Strictly speaking, the beam oak differs little from the actual oak, at least in terms of quality. But there is one special feature that makes the difference. The beam oak has an above-average number of growth cracks and knotholes and, as the name suggests, is composed of individual beams. While the wild oak is fine, noble and expressively grained, the beam oak looks much more rustic.
However, the wood is not sorted out because of such quality defects, as is normally the case with other furniture, but each individual wood is used for production.
